node.text:
Dopamine and Testosterone collaborate to create our motivated states, our desire to push forward toward goals and our willingness to meet challenges of all kinds. 
-
The key is ALL kinds. Testosterone and Dopamine don’t create goals or behaviors they create an action state in the body that makes all people, men and women, more willing to engage in effort to reach for whatever it is that we personally find desirable. 
-
Here I discuss that process with Dr. Robert Sapolsky
on The Huberman Lab Podcast.
-
Find the full episode (in all formats with time stamps and captions) by following the link in my profile bio. 
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nccih.gov
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #testosterone #dopamine #motivation #drive #will #energy #metabolism #intensity

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast with guest Dr Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D.  from @stanford.med @stanford 
-
There are so many misconceptions about testosterone and what it does to human thinking and behavior. 
-
Here we discuss the science of testosterone on the brain and how testosterone serves to amplify pre-existing tendencies and behaviors, effort and competition *even if that competition involves no aggression at all.*
-
Find the full episode in all formats with time stamps and captions by following the link in my profile bio. 
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-

@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nccih.gov
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #testosterone #aggression #libido #kindness #baboon #human #competition #status #win #fight #lose #cooperation

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast episode out now on Depression and how to treat it. 
-
One of the most striking features of major depression is how it changes the narrative of the person suffering, even to the point where they are disconnected from reality in a way that makes them genuinely underestimate their performance in life.
-
In the full episode (link in bio) I caution against self diagnosing depression. However it is important to take signs such as anti-self confabulation and the other symptoms seriously; I explain what those are, how to get an accurate diagnosis and some of the different forms of treatment. 
-
I also discuss some of the science supportive tools for keeping depression at bay and offer protocols.
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post and as always thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @bbrfoundation 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociência #depression #dementia
#serotonin #dopamine #confabulation #mentalhealth #physicalhealth

node.text:
A new study published in Cell Reports @cellpress found that ingesting protein (and BCAAs: branch chain amino acids) early in the day (active phase of circadian cycle) led to greater degrees of muscle maintenance and growth. (The study was done in mice and humans and identified mechanism… so it’s not just “phenomenology”). 
-
The basic take away is that for sake of muscle maintenance and growth, ingesting high-quality proteins early in the day is key. This is because of variations in gene expression in muscle cells across the circadian (24-hour cycle).
-
Note: The study did not mention anything detrimental about ingesting protein later in the evening or all day. Those of you intermittent fasting take note, however; you may wish to adjust your eating window accordingly.
-
Also: I would be remiss if I didn’t acknowledge that @timferriss suggested 30g quality protein within ~30min of waking in his book The 4-Hour Body. Science is catching up and bringing mechanistic insight and it’s great to see the convergence.
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post, and thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 

#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #protein #muscle #circadian #grip #bcaas #hypertrophy #fitness #physicalfitness #health #intermittentfasting #breakfast #eat

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast on Depression. Adequate levels of serotonin in the brain are crucial for maintaining healthy mood.
-
Ingesting sufficient levels of EPA fatty acids and getting sufficient exercise have been explored as both treatments and preventatives for depression. There are now many quality peer reviewed studies supporting their use — sometimes alone and sometimes in combination with other therapies.
-
Here I explain how EPAs and exercise work in this context: they prevent neural inflammation and divert neurotoxic metabolites of tryptophan, allowing more serotonin to be synthesized in the brain. 
-
A link to the full episode - with more details and specific protocols and links to the articles on EPA etc- can be found in my profile bio or by going to hubermanlab.com
-
Meanwhile, please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress @bbrfoundation 
-

node.text:
Excerpt from the new Huberman Lab Podcast all about depression. Creatine, known for its role in improving physical performance has also been shown (in several quality clinical trials) to improve mood and help the symptoms of major depression.
-
Everyone’s situation is different but this may be useful in thinking about ways to maintain healthy mood and to stave off depression. There’s also an emerging evidence on enhancement of other aspects of cognitive function but more studies are needed there..
-
A link to the full episode - with links the articles on creatine- can be found in my profile bio. Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science. 
-

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast with Dr Anna Lembke, MD (Chief of the Addiction Medicine Dual Diagnosis Clinic @stanford.med )
-
This was our conversation about “how to find your passion”. It involves linking your dopamine system to immediate action steps NOT stationary soul searching for what calls you. 
-
Why? The reason is that behaviors you initiate and that impact your immediate environment shift your dopamine system to a more functional state that you control. That is proven in helping people recover from addictions but it is also a fundamental route for finding one’s calling in life.
-
That might seem counterintuitive but I can attest that all the high performers I know in academia, sports, business, (indeed all realms of life), are also extremely responsible to their immediate surroundings and constantly live in the question of how they can serve others. Later they may outsource some of that more immediate work but that is after they have succeeded, not on the way up. 
-
Don’t be misled by some of the more salient examples of success that fail to show the more mundane steps people take to arrive at those high positions. 
-
To hear more of our discussion about dopamine, passion, addiction, and how all people— not just addicts, can maximize their relationship to the dopamine system, check out the full episode of Huberman Lab Podcast (the link is in my profile bio. It’s in all formats audio and video, with captioning English in Spanish, time stamps etc.)
-
Meanwhile please put your questions in the comments section below. Suggestions for future episodes also welcome. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-

node.text:
Excerpt from new episode of The Huberman Lab Podcast where I talk to Dr. Anna Lembke, MD: Chief of the Stanford Addiction Medicine Dual Diagnosis Clinic @stanford.med 
-
There are many different reasons why people become addicted to substances or behaviors. And there are equally many things to which we can become addicted to. What most people don’t realize however is that all forms of addiction, yes all, share a common biological mechanism. It is a disruption in the neural circuits that control “pain-pleasure balance”. Here we discuss how those circuits work.
-
The wonderful thing about understanding mechanism and the fact that there is a common one to all addictions is that there is also a common route to recovery. In the episode we describe that route as well.
-
You can find the episode in all formats (& captioned in English and Spanish) at the link in my bio or by going to hubermanlab.com
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. I will be hosting a special live discussion related to your most common questions, later this week. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress
-
[Top card illustration: Viktor Koen]
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #addiction #relapse #dopamine #recovery #pain #pleasure #truth #mentalhealth #mechanism #depression #addictionrecovery

node.text:
Acupuncture has been used for thousands of years. Recently, it is achieved more widespread use and acceptance as a viable treatment for pain. The data indicate that some people respond very well to acupuncture for the treatment of pain where as other people do not. 
-
Recent studies @harvardmed on the mechanisms underlying acupuncture discovered that stimulation of some sides on the body made inflammation worse, rest stimulation on other sites were anti-inflammatory. Especially exciting is that the studies identify the specific neural pathways and neurochemicals that mediated these divergent effects. 
-
Here I explain those results. I delve deeper into the biology of pain and pleasure, and treatments for pain and for increasing pleasure in the new episode of the Huberman Lab Podcast. 
-
You can find the link to that episode in all formats (and with captions and time stamps) in my profile bio. Meanwhile, please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 
@cellpress 
-

node.text:
Dopamine is not the molecule pleasure it is the molecule of motivation. Its patterns of release dictate how willing you are to work for a goal. Here I describe how reward and anticipation schedules impact your dopamine release. 
-
You can use this information to build and maintain motivation and to avoid disappointment and “low motivation”. 
-
There’s no way around hard work but with proper patterns of dopamine release: what we call “dopamine schedules”, hard work arrives far more easily. Just remember not to reward something every time or on a predictable schedule. That’s a path to failure over time. Reward intermittently.
-
There’s a Huberman Lab Podcast episode all about motivation. You can find it by following the link in my profile bio and scrolling down to the motivation episode. Lots more science and tools related to motivation can be found there. 
-
Meanwhile, please put any questions that you have in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 
@cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #dopamine #reward #motivation #drive #driven #push #reward #win #lose #relentless #disappointment #satisfy #anticipation #hungry #eager #patient

node.text:
Viewing light impacts our sleep and alertness by way of two major hormone systems: cortisol and melatonin. It also impacts our mood through a separate pathway involving a brain area called the habenula. Finally, viewing sunlight can adjust metabolism and release of hormones like testosterone and estrogen through hypothalamic (brain) pathways that act independently of sleep. 
-
Here I describe those 3 major biological pathways and protocols to optimize them.
-
Please put any questions you have or suggestions for future episodes in the comments section below this post and thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-

node.text:
Excerpt from my discussion with Dr. Matt Walker @drmattwalker , on The Huberman Lab Podcast Episode out now: “Perfecting Your Sleep”. 
-
We discuss all aspects of sleep, including deep and REM sleep, dreaming and behavioral and supplement-based tools to access deep, restorative sleep on a regular basis. (Note: Many of these tools have not been discussed in recorded format prior to the conversation).
-
You can find our episode in video or audio by following the link in my profile bio. Everything is time stamped and captioned in English and Spanish.
-
Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. Also if you have suggestions for future episodes please put them in the comments section. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience
-

node.text:
Dopamine and Testosterone collaborate to create our motivated states, our desire to push forward toward goals and our willingness to meet challenges of all kinds. 
-
The key is ALL kinds. Testosterone and Dopamine don’t create goals or behaviors they create an action state in the body that makes all people, men and women, more willing to engage in effort to reach for whatever it is that we personally find desirable. 
-
Here I discuss that process with Dr. Robert Sapolsky
on The Huberman Lab Podcast.
-
Find the full episode (in all formats with time stamps and captions) by following the link in my profile bio. 
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nccih.gov
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #testosterone #dopamine #motivation #drive #will #energy #metabolism #intensity

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast with guest Dr Robert Sapolsky, Ph.D.  from @stanford.med @stanford 
-
There are so many misconceptions about testosterone and what it does to human thinking and behavior. 
-
Here we discuss the science of testosterone on the brain and how testosterone serves to amplify pre-existing tendencies and behaviors, effort and competition *even if that competition involves no aggression at all.*
-
Find the full episode in all formats with time stamps and captions by following the link in my profile bio. 
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-

@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nccih.gov
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #testosterone #aggression #libido #kindness #baboon #human #competition #status #win #fight #lose #cooperation

node.text:
HUBERMAN LAB PODCAST WITH:
DR. ROBERT SAPOLSKY, Ph.D.
PROFESSOR of BIOLOGY, NEUROSURGERY at STANFORD
TOPIC: “STRESS, TESTOSTERONE & FREE WILL” 
-
We discuss stress and how our choice of method to limit our stress impacts if it helps or harms us. 
-
We also discuss the many myths about testosterone and the truth of how behaviors can dramatically change testosterone levels in men and women. Also how, mechanistically, “testosterone makes effort feel good”. Hint: amygdala.
- 
Then we discuss hormone replacement therapy in women, how timing is key and how testosterone in both men and women impacts social ranking, aggression and mating behavior. Also, the essential role of estrogen in brain health and longevity. 
-
Then we discuss free will and Dr Sapolsky’s book (in the works) on whether we have free will and how knowledge of biological mechanisms can help shape our choices. 
-
You can find the episode in all formats by following the link in my profile bio. All topics are time stamped. 
-
Also: Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. (Live discussion on them later this week). And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress [photo: L.A. Cicero @stanford.med]
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #stress #testosterone #estrogen #prolactin #aggression #mates #biology #robertsapolsky #behave #menopause #testes #crocodile #freewill #bloodpressure #fight #rank #primate

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Andrew Huberman, Ph.D. in Stanford, California with @hubermanlab. May be a Twitter screenshot of 1 person and text that says 'Andrew D. Huberman, Ph.D. @hubermanlab It's remarkable that, *far more than any of our own behaviors (besides mating)* observing the successful aggression of others we deem "our team" raises our testosterone levels most. This is true for both males and females. The takeaway: mere perceptions can influence hormones.'.

node.text:
OUR PERCEPTIONS INFLUENCE OUR HORMONES… INDEPENDENTLY of OUR BEHAVIOR. 
-
Certain behaviors can change our hormone levels. Among them, the effects of mating on testosterone and estrogen levels, and post-mating increases in prolactin (which are dramatic and for a time prevent further mating). But often overlooked is the fact that perceptions, not just behaviors can dramatically impact the levels of hormone such as testosterone. This is true for both males and females, and has been shown in humans and other old world primates.
-
One of the most dramatic examples of this is the observation of our favorite team, or any that we deem us/our affiliates, exerting dominant aggression on another team. Conversely, when our affiliates lose we experience drops in these hormones. It’s amazing that these impacts are often greater than our own direct wins and losses.
-
If you think about it this is remarkable because it involves no change in our own behavior. It is 100% perceptual. Our brain has a dramatic effect on our physiology at the level of perception, right down to our hormone levels.
-
More on this topic tomorrow on the Huberman Lab Podcast. 
-
Meanwhile please put your questions in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #hormones #perception #testosterone #estrogen #winners #losers #us #them #primates #competition #aggression #affiliate #prolactin #love #war #friendship

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast episode out now on Depression and how to treat it. 
-
One of the most striking features of major depression is how it changes the narrative of the person suffering, even to the point where they are disconnected from reality in a way that makes them genuinely underestimate their performance in life.
-
In the full episode (link in bio) I caution against self diagnosing depression. However it is important to take signs such as anti-self confabulation and the other symptoms seriously; I explain what those are, how to get an accurate diagnosis and some of the different forms of treatment. 
-
I also discuss some of the science supportive tools for keeping depression at bay and offer protocols.
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post and as always thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @bbrfoundation 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociência #depression #dementia
#serotonin #dopamine #confabulation #mentalhealth #physicalhealth

node.text:
A new study published in Cell Reports @cellpress found that ingesting protein (and BCAAs: branch chain amino acids) early in the day (active phase of circadian cycle) led to greater degrees of muscle maintenance and growth. (The study was done in mice and humans and identified mechanism… so it’s not just “phenomenology”). 
-
The basic take away is that for sake of muscle maintenance and growth, ingesting high-quality proteins early in the day is key. This is because of variations in gene expression in muscle cells across the circadian (24-hour cycle).
-
Note: The study did not mention anything detrimental about ingesting protein later in the evening or all day. Those of you intermittent fasting take note, however; you may wish to adjust your eating window accordingly.
-
Also: I would be remiss if I didn’t acknowledge that @timferriss suggested 30g quality protein within ~30min of waking in his book The 4-Hour Body. Science is catching up and bringing mechanistic insight and it’s great to see the convergence.
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post, and thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience 

#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #protein #muscle #circadian #grip #bcaas #hypertrophy #fitness #physicalfitness #health #intermittentfasting #breakfast #eat

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast on Depression. Adequate levels of serotonin in the brain are crucial for maintaining healthy mood.
-
Ingesting sufficient levels of EPA fatty acids and getting sufficient exercise have been explored as both treatments and preventatives for depression. There are now many quality peer reviewed studies supporting their use — sometimes alone and sometimes in combination with other therapies.
-
Here I explain how EPAs and exercise work in this context: they prevent neural inflammation and divert neurotoxic metabolites of tryptophan, allowing more serotonin to be synthesized in the brain. 
-
A link to the full episode - with more details and specific protocols and links to the articles on EPA etc- can be found in my profile bio or by going to hubermanlab.com
-
Meanwhile, please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress @bbrfoundation 
-
#neuroscience #science #ciencia #neurociencia #depression #happy #sad #inflammation #tryptophan #serotonin #exercise #physicalfitness #mentalhealth #fishoil #krill #epa

node.text:
Excerpt from the new Huberman Lab Podcast all about depression. Creatine, known for its role in improving physical performance has also been shown (in several quality clinical trials) to improve mood and help the symptoms of major depression.
-
Everyone’s situation is different but this may be useful in thinking about ways to maintain healthy mood and to stave off depression. There’s also an emerging evidence on enhancement of other aspects of cognitive function but more studies are needed there..
-
A link to the full episode - with links the articles on creatine- can be found in my profile bio. Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post. Thank you for your interest in science. 
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress @bbrfoundation

node.text:
HUBERMAN LAB PODCAST: ALL ABOUT DEPRESSION & GETTING RELIEF FROM DEPRESSION •
-
There’s a lot of misunderstanding about what depression is. I hope that coaches, teachers, parents, therapists— indeed all individuals, will consider learning about this condition, and how to prevent and treat it. 
-
This episode I explain the 3 chemical systems altered in depression: norepinephrine, serotonin and dopamine, and the role of physical pain in depression. Also: genetic predispositions to depression and the role of stress, thyroid hormone and cortisol. 
-
I describe 8 science-supported protocols for treating and *for avoiding* depression, including EPA fatty acids (which have been shown to rival certain prescription treatments,  but only at certain dosages), how exercise protects against depression at the mechanistic level and antidepressant effects of studies of creatine (and how they work). 
-
I also discuss the clinical trials for ketamine and psilocybin for depression treatment, and how ketogenic diets may help in certain cases of depression, especially treatment-resistant major depression.
-
A link to the episode can be found in my profile bio. Please put any questions you have in the comments section below this post …and thank you for your interest in science!
-
Photo credit: @blabacphoto 
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress @bbrfoundation 
-

node.text:
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast with Dr Anna Lembke, MD (Chief of the Addiction Medicine Dual Diagnosis Clinic @stanford.med )
-
This was our conversation about “how to find your passion”. It involves linking your dopamine system to immediate action steps NOT stationary soul searching for what calls you. 
-
Why? The reason is that behaviors you initiate and that impact your immediate environment shift your dopamine system to a more functional state that you control. That is proven in helping people recover from addictions but it is also a fundamental route for finding one’s calling in life.
-
That might seem counterintuitive but I can attest that all the high performers I know in academia, sports, business, (indeed all realms of life), are also extremely responsible to their immediate surroundings and constantly live in the question of how they can serve others. Later they may outsource some of that more immediate work but that is after they have succeeded, not on the way up. 
-
Don’t be misled by some of the more salient examples of success that fail to show the more mundane steps people take to arrive at those high positions. 
-
To hear more of our discussion about dopamine, passion, addiction, and how all people— not just addicts, can maximize their relationship to the dopamine system, check out the full episode of Huberman Lab Podcast (the link is in my profile bio. It’s in all formats audio and video, with captioning English in Spanish, time stamps etc.)
-
Meanwhile please put your questions in the comments section below. Suggestions for future episodes also welcome. Thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress 
-

node.text:
TRUTH TELLING STRENGTHENS THE NEURAL CIRCUITS THAT LIMIT IMPULSIVITY•
-
Excerpt from Huberman Lab Podcast where I talk to Dr. Anna Lembke, MD: Chief of the Stanford Addiction Medicine Dual Diagnosis Clinic @stanford.med 
-
There are now good data showing that lying of any kind, (whether you are an addict or not), alters the way that your brain works by increasing impulsivity. Truth telling does the opposite. 
-
Dr Lembke discusses this further in her new book: Dopamine Nation: Finding Balance in the Age of Indulgence. It’s an incredible read on dopamine, addiction and for non-addicts too, as it explains human motivation and how to maintain access to our sense of pleasure. 
-
You can find this episode in all formats (& captioned in English and Spanish) at the link in my bio or by going to hubermanlab.com
-
Please put your questions in the comments section below this post. And thank you for your interest in science!
-
@hubermanlab @stanford.med @stanford @nihgov @nimhgov @nih_nccih @societyforneuroscience @cellpress
-
